Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enabling Computation on Encrypted Data on the Cloud and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enhance data security by solving the current problem of securing data in use through encryption. It has the potential to build trust on the cloud by overcoming the technical challenges of building a fully homomorphic encryption solution. This will allow data owners to encrypt their confidential data and process that encrypted data without constraints or having to decrypt it first. This important new capability will enable further data migration to the cloud and a new secure Encrypted Data-as-a-Service (EDaaS) model where: (i) confidential data can be used for analyses or machine learning while encrypted and as a service, without ever being decrypted or shared without encryption; and (ii) data owners can authorize users to access their encrypted data while maintaining control and authority. In short, data owners will be able to securely migrate confidential data to the cloud and maintain full privacy and security, even for commercial use.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will investigate and validate the feasibility and performance of an innovative obfuscation method that can be applied to allow the unconstrained processing of encrypted data. This patent-pending method is based on reversible computing to build homomorphic encryption functions by obfuscating bare functions combined with encryption/decryption operators. Libraries of these functions can then serve as a building block for generic and specialized calculations on encrypted data. To prove feasibility, this Phase I project addresses three technical hurdles: (i) validation of the method to ensure the security of data and functions, (ii) optimization of performance relative to existing homomorphic encryption schemes, and (iii) connectivity to existing analytical tools and cloud environments to host and process data. The goal of this research project is to develop a method for simple, fast, and flexible homomorphic encryption that can be integrated with existing analytical processes in private as well as public environments, such as the cloud, for commercial success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data is the most valuable resource in the world, and computer algorithms are very thirsty for it: more and more data is needed to train computer models to better predict outcomes and behaviors. In contrast, policy makers are rightfully demanding robust confidentiality and privacy of personal information, and creating regulation to protect data against abuses and breaches. Unfortunately, the result so far has been to build dividing walls and force data into silos, often making it impractical to use and extract its full value. But instead of silos and separation, the best way to protect personal data (or any kind of data) is still through encryption. That can be straightforward for data in storage or in transit, but not yet for data in use (exactly that data being processed by those insatiable algorithms). Much research on this topic (also known as homomorphic encryption) has been done by academics and technology leaders to fill that security gap that could allow data to stay encrypted and secure at all times, but has so far had limited success making it usable and scalable.

USEncryption has a new disruptive approach to enable computation on encrypted data: it employs reversible computing and a patented method to build libraries of encrypted functions by obfuscating the reversible circuit representations of plain functions combined with encryption/decryption circuits. The goal of this SBIR project is to research and develop the unconstrained processing of encrypted data without having to decrypt it first, thus to (i) definitively solve the persistent challenge of Data in Use security to allow data to stay encrypted at all times – even while being processed – and (ii) unlock opportunities to share confidential data with full privacy and security, powered by encryption and never compromising the unencrypted data.

Through the research performed in our Phase I project, we realized the need to keep our circuits small enough for practical use. With that goal, we tested a powerful patent-pending improvement of the method that can reduce the number of gates and thus lead to obfuscated circuits that are several orders of magnitude shorter, without compromising security. In addition to that important conclusion:

  • our customer discovery interviews helped us identify machine learning as our most relevant use case;
  • our development work to accelerate the software evaluator of encrypted functions helped us outperform competing methods; and
  • our extensive experimentation concluded that only transitioning our solution to hardware can achieve the performance required for real-world applications, such as machine learning on encrypted data, essential to make the technology commercially viable. 

Data is the fuel that powers the new economy but is still in its early days of exploitation and regulation. We believe our research can have significant impact on broad industries such as financial services, health care and government, including: 

  • enabling the sharing of data with privacy and security, not only for the data-driven enterprise but also for research and government;
  • allowing further innovation in all types of confidential data-dependent research and business models, for instance medical discoveries that can improve the health and welfare of the American public;
  • making data more available and less concentrated in the hands of “Big Tech”, fostering innovation among other small and medium-size companies; and 
  • accelerating current trends to extract value from data thus improve efficiencies and productivity in the global economy.

USEncryption was founded to take to market a ground-breaking method invented by academics to solve a long-standing security gap for Data in Use, with significant impact on cybersecurity and the data economy. Our main purpose is to bring the promise of this innovative academic work to its full potential in industry and government. We have built a first prototype that has powered our experiments and pilot client discussions so far, and look forward to using our Phase I conclusions to further research and develop a solution in Phase II that can be successfully taken to market.
